title: 115_s1467
content: The Act is titled the "Wounded Warrior Workforce Enhancement Act" and focuses on improving education in orthotics and prosthetics. The "Wounded Warrior Workforce Enhancement Act" aims to award grants to eligible institutions for establishing or expanding master's degree programs in orthotics and prosthetics, with priority given to those partnering with VA medical centers or clinics. The "Wounded Warrior Workforce Enhancement Act" authorizes grants of $1,000,000 to $1,500,000 for eligible institutions to establish or expand orthotics and prosthetics master's degree programs, with priority for those partnering with VA or DoD facilities. The Secretary will issue requests for proposals annually for two years. The "Wounded Warrior Workforce Enhancement Act" authorizes grants for eligible institutions to establish or expand orthotics and prosthetics master's degree programs. Grant recipients must demonstrate willingness to participate in a partnership and commit to maintaining an accredited program after the grant period. Grant funds can be used for building or expanding master's degree programs and training doctoral candidates in related fields. The "Wounded Warrior Workforce Enhancement Act" authorizes grants for eligible institutions to establish or expand orthotics and prosthetics master's degree programs. Grant funds can be used for faculty training, salary supplementation, financial aid for students, faculty research projects, and building renovations. The "Wounded Warrior Workforce Enhancement Act" authorizes grants for eligible institutions to establish or expand orthotics and prosthetics master's degree programs. Grant funds can be used for building renovations, equipment purchases, admissions preference for veterans, and a three-year period for fund utilization. In this section, an eligible institution is defined as one that offers an orthotics and prosthetics education program accredited by the National Commission on Orthotic and Prosthetic Education. The term "veteran" is defined as per section 101 of title 38, United States Code. Authorization of $15,000,000 for the Department of Veterans Affairs in fiscal year 2018 under section 101 of title 38, United States Code. Any unobligated amounts by September 30, 2020, will be returned to the Treasury. The Center of Excellence in Orthotic and Prosthetic Education is established. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs awards a grant to establish the Center of Excellence in Orthotic and Prosthetic Education, focusing on improving outcomes through evidence-based research on necessary knowledge, skills, and training for clinical professionals in the field. The Secretary prioritizes grants to institutions willing to collaborate with federal agencies or private sector entities to provide resources and research assistance to the Center of Excellence in Orthotic and Prosthetic Education. The Secretary will issue a request for proposals for a $5,000,000 grant for orthotics and prosthetic research. Eligible institutions must submit applications with required information. The grant recipient must use the funds to develop an agenda for orthotics. The grant aims to support research in orthotics and prosthetics education, fund research projects, and disseminate findings. The eligible institution can use the grant for five years. Eligible institutions must have a strong research program and an accredited orthotics and prosthetics education program. The Department of Veterans Affairs is authorized to appropriate $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2018 to support orthotics and prosthetics education. Eligible institutions must have established associations with a medical center or clinic of the Department of Veterans Affairs and a local rehabilitation hospital. The term "veteran" is defined in section 101 of title 38, United States Code.
